episodes.subtitle: Neko Atsume is a strange game to describe. It's a…
episodes.description: Neko Atsume is a strange game to describe. It's a strange game to play. And it's the game that, more than any other, Polygon reporter Allegra Frank thought about when she looked back on 2015. Today on Polygon Minimap: Worldmap Edition, we focus on a weird game. Or at least that's what we thought we were going to do. We got a lot more. It's funny how these things work sometimes. You start talking about Neko Atsume, and before you know it, you're discovering important truths about video games — about why we play them, about when we play the, about why even those that might turn a recent college graduate into a self-described "crazy cat lady" wind up staying with us months later. episodes.subtitle: In 2015, it was the best of times, it was the wor…
episodes.description: In 2015, it was the best of times, it was the worst of times for Metal Gear. Charles Dickens wrote that (we think), and he was right: It was a weird year for Hideo Kojima, Konami and the Metal Gear franchise. Throughout the year, there were whispers and rumors that things had gone awry between the man who created the stealthy franchise and the company where he'd worked for three decades. It was difficult to see those rumors reflected when Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain arrived in September to critical acclaim. The game even earned a top spot (http://is.gd/BUMKjN) in Polygon's 2015 Game of the Year list. But by mid-December, we learned the truth: Kojima and Konami were no longer partners. What the heck happened? Senior reporter Samit Sarkar dove into years worth of news stories to recount the relationship's devolution (http://is.gd/u4VjLN). And today, he's our very special guest on an episode of our Minimap podcast to talk about the bitter breakup. Welcome to Polygon Minimap: Worldmap Edition, a roundtable discussion about the most interesting stories in gaming, entertainment and pop culture. In today's episode, you'll hear Samit and your host Dave Tach trace the relationship back decades and help make a long and complicated story easy to understand. episodes.subtitle: You’ve heard about Destiny. How could you not? S…
episodes.description: You’ve heard about Destiny. How could you not? Stories about Bungie’s first-person shooter/massively multiplayer online role-playing game were a constant in 2015’s news stream, including on Minimap. Why? Because Destiny is a fascinating and popular game that’s in a constant state of evolution, and players crave information. Popular as it may be, though, Destiny is also a game that even its most devoted players consider to be flawed in some fundamental ways. This year was huge year for Destiny, bringing changes that made the game better than its ever been. Here at the end of 2015, Destiny is not the same game it was at the beginning of the year. And that trend shows every indication of continuing in 2016 and beyond. But it’s still a work in progress. In this episode, we’ve assembled our largest panel ever to discuss Destiny. Our panelists have logged nearly 2,000 hours of playtime, but it’s not a discussion designed for Destiny enthusiasts. Instead, it’s about figuring Destiny out. Why is the game so popular? What pulls so many in? What keeps players coming back? Our discussion answers those questions and plenty more, including those about the game’s problematic past and what the future may hold. Welcome to Polygon Minimap: Worldmap Edition, a roundtable discussion about the most interesting stories in gaming, entertainment and pop culture. Press play to hear Jake Lear, Griffin McElroy, Mike McWhertor, Jeff Ramos, Samit Sarkar and your host Dave Tach discuss Bungie’s fascinating shooter. Find out more about Minimap — and subscribe to get every episode free of charge as soon as it's released — at http://www.polygon.com/minimap
episodes.title: Why do so many people play so much Destiny?

episodes.subtitle: Minimap is your daily audio tour through the worl…
episodes.description: Minimap is your daily audio tour through the world of video games, related technologies and pop culture like comics, movies and TV. And today, we're doing something for the very first time. We call it Worldmap. Polygon Minimap's Worldmap Edition will air every Friday. In addition to the most interesting news of the day, it will include on-staff experts who not only talk about current events, but analyze and synthesize them. Think of Worldmap as the director's commentary for Polygon. Today, we're joined by Charlie Hall, who's been reporting on Fig for weeks. It's a new and potentially disruptive addition to the crowdfunding ecosystem that Kickstarter, well, kickstarted a few years ago. Charlie's the expert, and he's going to unfurl his knowledge to explain everything from who's involved to what millionaires and the SEC have to do with it and whether or not the first game funded is an unqualified success. Then, Phil Kollar will debrief us on his recent trip to the very first TwitchCon. He'll tell us what it was like to be there, what made it significant and what the ramifications are when 20,000 streamers, Twitch celebrities and fans gather in San Francisco. But before that, as always, there's the news.
